(MBA '76) | period = 1980-present | genre = Pre-historical [[fiction]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = [[Earth's Children|Earth's Children series]] | spouse = Ray Bernard Auel | children = 5 | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Jean Marie Auel''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|Ë|dÊ|iË|n|_|_|m|É|Ë|r|iË|_|Ë|aÊ|l}}; born February 18, 1936) is an [[United States|American]] writer. She is best known for her [[Earth's Children]] books, a series of novels set in [[prehistoric Europe]] that explores interactions of [[Cro-Magnon]] people with [[Neanderthals]]. As of 2010 her books have sold over 45 million copies worldwide.[http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/book-news/deals/article/43338-new-jean-m-auel.html Publisher's Weekly] ==Early years== Born '''Jean Marie Untinen''' on February 18, 1936 in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]],{{cite web| url= http://www.bluebook.state.or.us/notable/notauel.htm | title=Notable Oregonians: Jean Auel - Writer | publisher=[[Oregon Blue Book]]| date=January 2009 | accessdate=2010-05-03}} she is of Finnish descent, the second of five children of Neil Solomon Untinen, a housepainter, and Martha Wirtanen. Auel attended [[Portland State University]].{{citation needed|date=May 2010}} While a student, she joined [[Mensa International|Mensa]],{{cite journal | title = They're Accomplished, They're Famous, and They're Mensans | journal = Mensa Bulletin | publisher = American Mensa | id = ISSN 0025-9543 | year = 2004 | month = July | issue = 476 | pages = 27 }} and worked at [[Tektronix]], as a clerk (1965â66), a circuit board designer (1966â73), technical writer (1973â74), and a credit manager (1974â76).{{citation needed|date=May 2010}} At one time, she shared a secretary with the author [[Ursula K. Le Guin]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}} Auel earned an [[Master of Business Administration]] from the [[University of Portland]] in 1976,{{cite web| url=http://www.up.edu/alumni/default.aspx?cid=7480&pid=2850 | title=Alumni: Distinguished Alumni Awards| publisher=[[University of Portland]] |accessdate=2010-05=03}} and she has been awarded honorary degrees from her ''alma mater'', the [[University of Maine]], and the [[Mount Vernon College for Women]].{{citation needed|date=May 2010}} ==Career as novelist== In 1977, Auel began extensive library research of the [[Ice Age]] for her first book. She joined a [[survival skills|survival class]] to learn how to construct an ice cave, and learned primitive methods of making fire, tanning leather, and knapping stone from the [[indigenous peoples|aboriginal]] skills expert Jim Riggs.[http://books.google.com/books?id=cxI3snAr_7IC&pg=PP8&lpg=PP8&dq=jean+auel+jim+riggs&source=bl&ots=wMuEaIyWtl&sig=K-BHD4pVacSLIQo_oP2LKiuPWY4&hl=en&ei=zwRMTdS3HZG6sQOAhvmQCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&sqi=2&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCQ The Valley of Horses - Acknowledgements] ''[[The Clan of the Cave Bear]]'' was nominated for numerous literary awards, including an [[American Booksellers Association]] nomination for best first novel.[http://www.randomhouse.com/features/auel/webroot/authorqa.html Jean M. Auel :: Author Q&A] from [[Random House]] It was also later adapted into a screenplay for [[The Clan of the Cave Bear (film)|the film of the same name]]. After the sales success of her first book, Auel has been able to travel to the sites of prehistoric ruins and relics, and also to meet many of the experts with whom she had been corresponding. Her research has taken her across [[Europe]] from [[France]] to [[Ukraine]], including most of what [[Marija Gimbutas]] called [[Old European culture|Old Europe]]. In 1986 she attended and co-sponsored a conference on modern human origins at the School of American Research, Santa Fe.Stringer, Christopher & Gamble, Clive ''In Search of the Neanderthals'' plate 96 (1993, Thames and Hudson, London) ISBN 0 500 27807 5 She has developed a close friendship with Dr. Jean Clottes of France who was responsible for, among many other things, the exploration of the [[Cosquer Cave]] discovered in 1985 and the [[Chauvet Cave]] discovered in 1994.[http://www.randomhouse.com/features/auel/webroot/video.html Jean M. Auel :: Video Interviews] from [[Random House]][http://donsmaps.com/auel.html "An Evening With Jean Auel"] from donsmaps.com In October 2008, Auel was named an Officer of the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] by the French Minister of Culture and Communication.{{cite web| title=Jean Auel wins French award | date=October 13, 2008 | url= http://blog.oregonlive.com/books/2008/10/jean_auel_wins_french_award.html | publisher=[[The Oregonian]] | work= Bookmarks (a literary blog)| author=Jeff Baker| accessdate=2010-05-04}} ==Bibliography== By 1990, Auel's first three books in her ''[[Earth's Children]]'' series sold more than 20 million copies worldwide and had been translated into 18 languages; [[Crown Publishing Group|Crown Publishers]] has reportedly paid Auel about $25 million for the rights to publish ''The Plains of Passage'' and the two subsequent volumes.{{cite web | url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,971440,00.html | title= Books: Queen of The Ice Age Romance | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date= October 22, 1990 | accessdate=2010-05-04}} By May 2002, on the cusp of the publication of the fifth book, the series had sold 34 million books.{{cite web | url=http://www.time.com/time/printout/0,8816,971440,00.html | title= Books: Romancing The Stone Age | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date= May 13, 2002 | accessdate=2010-05-04}} On May 27, 2010, it was announced that the sixth and final book in the series, ''The Land of Painted Caves'', would be published March 29, 2011.{{cite web | url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/book-news/deals/article/43338-new-jean-m-auel.html | title=New Jean Auel | date= May 27, 2010 | accessdate=2010-05-27}} # ''[[The Clan of the Cave Bear]]'', 1980 # ''[[The Valley of Horses]]'', 1982 # ''[[The Mammoth Hunters]]'', 1985 # ''[[The Plains of Passage]]'', 1990 # ''[[The Shelters of Stone]]'', 2002 # ''[[The Land of Painted Caves]]'', 2011 == Personal life == Auel married Ray Bernard Auel after high school.
